Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will address a current limitation in manufacturing of electronic devices. At the heart of electronic device manufacturing is the production of printed circuit boards (PCBs), which provide the mechanical support and electrical connection for electronic components. Many reliability issues associated with electronic devices result from non-uniformities in the electrodeposited copper on the PCBs. The drive for improved electronic device performance has necessitated shrinking PCB feature dimensions and increasing complexity of features, which has exacerbated this problem. The objective of this project is to develop sophisticated electrolyte flow schemes that will specifically target manufacturing issues associated with shrinking feature sizes and increased PCB complexity. The development and optimization of these sophisticated electrolyte flow schemes will enhance PCB reliability as well as improve manufacturing throughput for next generation electronic devices.

The boarder impact/commercial potential of this project is the production of robust,lower cost electronic devices, which are found in a vast number of end-products,including critical defense, monitoring and safety systems used by the US government and military. The market for electronic devices, estimated to be about a $1.3 trillion dollar industry, is formed by various sectors including computer and office equipment,
communication equipment, portable and consumer electronics, medical and automotive electronics. This technology specifically addresses the manufacture of printed circuit boards, a critical component of all electronic devices, which were estimated to be a $53.6 billion market in 2009. A large commercial driver for the ElectroCell technology is the ability to manufacture PCBs at a higher rate, improving throughput and lowering manufacturing costs. This will translate into lower cost electronics for consumers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Copper electrodeposition is a critical step in the manufacture of electronic components, such as printed circuit boards used in everyday devices ranging from smart phones to TVs. Reliability of these electronic components is directly tied to uniformity of the copper deposit within the features of the printed circuit boards.  In general, uniformity of the copper deposit is enhanced through use of low plating current densities and/or us of chemical additives in the plating bath.  The use of low current densities render the through-put slow and consequently drive the costs of the electronic components. The plating additives are also added to help achieve the desired mechanical properties of the copper deposit, such as tensile strength and elongation.  The additives are expensive in terms of cost as well as time in maintaining their parts per million concentrations.  This translates to a significant cost in the manufacture of printed circuit boards. 

 

In this NSF-sponsored program, Faraday Technology Inc. partnered with TTM Technologies (formerly Viasystems Group) for the development of a plating process that improves manufacturing through-put while maintaining performance when compared the current manufacturing capabilities.  Specifically, Faraday focused on activities to promote increased through-put and cost savings associated with the copper plating process as compared to current practice.  This program focused on the design, build and installation of a novel plating cell for high speed manufacture of electronic components. Based on NSF funded activities, four U.S. patents based on the FARADAYICÒ ElectroCell technology were issued (US Patent Numbers 7,553,401/7,947,161/8,226,804/8,329,006).  The FARADAYICÒ ElectroCell technology has been proven to deliver a very high level of uniformity for copper electrodeposits and has been experimentally benchmarked by multiple commercial electrodeposition cell geometries. 

 

Improvements to the copper electrodeposit uniformity over the current state of the art enables plating at higher current densities, translating into higher through-put, which is achieved while maintaining the properties desirable for printed circuit board applications.  With funding from TMM, Faraday delivered and installed a 25,000 gallon FARADAYIC ElectroCell at their California printed circuit board manufacturing facility. In addition, under the current program and continued funding from TTM, Faraday is working to develop a plating process (FARADAYIC® ElectroDeposition) that does not rely on the use bath additives.

 

Electronic devices are important to defense, medical and consumer markets. This NSF-sponsored program is anticipated to be beneficial for both defense, medical and consumer electronics as Faraday Technology partnered with a US-based, international manufacturer of printed circuit boards supplying to both segments of the market.  Furthermore, this NSF sponsored activity has enabled synergistic applications for the FARADAYIC® ElectroCell technology. For example, under a contract with the U.S. Army, Faraday is installing the FARADAYIC® ElectroCell technology at the Benet Laboratory facility as part of a recycling system. Specifically, the FARADAYIC® (R)ECM system captures valuable materials from the Benet Laboratory machining operations and conserves water usage. This installation is part of the U.S. Army “Net Zero Water Discharge” initiative for Army installations.  In addition, Faraday has established a business arrangement with a commercial company to use the FARADAYIC® ElectroCell technology for cost-effective manufacture of flow battery components. Flow batteries are critical to enable the implementation...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Copper electrodeposition is a critical step in the manufacture of electronic components, such as printed circuit boards used in everyday devices ranging from smart phones to TVs. Reliability of these electronic components is directly tied to uniformity of the copper deposit within the features of the printed circuit boards. In general, uniformity of the copper deposit is enhanced through use of low plating current densities and/or us of chemical additives in the plating bath. The use of low current densities render the through-put slow and consequently drive the costs of the electronic components. The plating additives are also added to help achieve the desired mechanical properties of the copper deposit, such as tensile strength and elongation. The additives are expensive in terms of cost as well as time in maintaining their parts per million concentrations. This translates to a significant cost in the manufacture of printed circuit boards. In this NSF-sponsored program, Faraday Technology Inc. partnered with TTM Technologies (formerly Viasystems Group) for the development of a plating process that improves manufacturing through-put while maintaining performance when compared the current manufacturing capabilities. Specifically, Faraday focused on activities to promote increased through-put and cost savings associated with the copper plating process as compared to current practice. This program focused on the design, build and installation of a novel plating cell for high speed manufacture of electronic components. Based on NSF funded activities, four U.S. patents based on the FARADAYICÒ ElectroCell technology were issued (US Patent Numbers 7,553,401/7,947,161/8,226,804/8,329,006). The FARADAYICÒ ElectroCell technology has been proven to deliver a very high level of uniformity for copper electrodeposits and has been experimentally benchmarked by multiple commercial electrodeposition cell geometries. Improvements to the copper electrodeposit uniformity over the current state of the art enables plating at higher current densities, translating into higher through-put, which is achieved while maintaining the properties desirable for printed circuit board applications. With funding from TMM, Faraday delivered and installed a 25,000 gallon FARADAYIC ElectroCell at their California printed circuit board manufacturing facility. In addition, under the current program and continued funding from TTM, Faraday is working to develop a plating process (FARADAYIC® ElectroDeposition) that does not rely on the use bath additives. Electronic devices are important to defense, medical and consumer markets. This NSF-sponsored program is anticipated to be beneficial for both defense, medical and consumer electronics as Faraday Technology partnered with a US-based, international manufacturer of printed circuit boards supplying to both segments of the market. Furthermore, this NSF sponsored activity has enabled synergistic applications for the FARADAYIC® ElectroCell technology. For example, under a contract with the U.S. Army, Faraday is installing the FARADAYIC® ElectroCell technology at the Benet Laboratory facility as part of a recycling system. Specifically, the FARADAYIC® (R)ECM system captures valuable materials from the Benet Laboratory machining operations and conserves water usage. This installation is part of the U.S. Army "Net Zero Water Discharge" initiative for Army installations. In addition, Faraday has established a business arrangement with a commercial company to use the FARADAYIC® ElectroCell technology for cost-effective manufacture of flow battery components. Flow batteries are critical to enable the implementation of renewable energy technologies such as wind and solar power. Last Modified: 12/30/2015 Submitted by: Holly M Garich
